Wz1AgQOzrHnzXBTs6YkvYQ.text: Senmi is a sashimi/sushi joint.We ordered California lobster roll and sashimi on rice.Both were good for the price but price for large Asahi was $9. Too much?Order through i-Pad at each table. Human servers.Service was efficient and polite.I'd come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Lobster (California) roll
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore

95VC3Pu5J8L4N3OlkvDjMg.text: Blech... I expected more from a sushi place in a Japanese specialty store, I should have known by the fact that the place was very quiet on a Friday night.On a positive note: I was seated immediately and ordering through the ipad system was easy. The food was served almost instantaneously so it was good for the quick bite I was looking for.Unfortunately I was also looking for something tasty and the quality of the sushi was below par. The sushi in my neighbourhood supermarket is of better quality quite honestly.The only thing which makes me not give it a lower rating is that some of the offerings on the menu looked quite inventive and were not your average sushi, but the fact that I walked past Sushi Express (who serve 2$ sushi) on my way back and regretted not going there says enough!

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Blue fin and sea urchin maki

obF_XT-PNIP8XhzSvw1zLg.text: Did an uber takeout with senmi sushi, Chirashi Don ($20.81) and Flamed Salmon Salad ($8.61) to be exact. The sashimi pieces were chunky and fresh, so was their rice lol. Would give a 3 half star for their dons, though did expect something more  judging from the number of stars and reviews they've gotten on Google. Flamed salmon salad (soury) was nice too, but isn't something uniquely different from other restaurants. Delivery and preparation was relatively fast around 30-35 minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Chirashi don (uber takeout)

odhvET7w-srpVlrLNRPSFA.text: 3.5 Decent sushi restaurant located inside the Emporium Shokuhin market! Japanese sushi restaurants in Singapore are either decently priced and so low in quality that you'd rather not eat it, or super expensive and awesome. except that the super expensive restaurants import the fish directly from Japan (and proudly boast about it) which D and I freak out and avoid at all costs...  so we've been looking for decent sushi places to eat on a normal day out. and Senmi sushi satisfies just that. Senmi sushi is not cheap, yet not so expensive, at around $19 each for chirashi and rolls- and the sushi is fresh and delicious. the restaurant ambiance is clean and inviting, being that it's located inside a recently opened new market. We got the seared salmon roll and the regular Chirashi bowl, which was fitting for two but Chirashi bowl was a bit on the smaller side. There's a chirashi bowl for 2~3 pax @ $35 option which we heard was great, will try next time!

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Seared salmon roll?
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Chirashi bowl

dfPFPzvRB_jHY1BqH7tMcg.text: I had gone to Gyuu before, and had some vouchers, so we decided to try a new place.  Opted for sushi as everything should be fresh and website photos kph great.  I'd say, for the price they charge, it really wasn't anything spectacular.  We ordered a cucumber furikake appetizer. This was good  ( but really couldn't go wrong with this dish). We ordered a thick cut chirashi Don, but it wasn't thick cut. Normal thin cut sashimi. I ordered a bluefin tuna temaki.  Usually temakis are a nice round cone, sure its usualky filled with more rice than fish, this....was a flat small cucumber sliced filled nori roll with some rice and a sprinkle of fish. Which i personally do not see it being worth the 6.80 price tag. Overall, the experience did not meet our expectations. I don't mind paying for something, as long as its good and as described in the menu. The emporium has many other restaurants, so I'd say go try the other ones out first....

etHvapHzxZBs7bWwMz6YgA.text: Been here several times. The Chirashi don and Sushi are very good. The sashimi was good in my previous visits but at our visit it wasn't as fresh. Still worth coming back though.

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Premium Chirashi Don.
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Sashimi platter.

dTs-YfsrIhRAfeLMebC0WA.text: Not going to this place again until there is a significant change... Made a booking before going. Online menu looks really tempting and the prices does not seem all that bad at that time... The place was rather empty when we arrived. Granted that it was a weekday and we were slightly early. Ordered via the ipad on the table (never a fan of ordering this way...), and food came quickly enough. The onsen tamago was decent (though this may be the reason for my vomiting after dinner... Or maybe that was due to the $6.80 single oyster... It will remain a mystery....). Temaki were a bit sad.... Flat piece of folded nori was presented... "Thick cut" chirachi was abit-less-than-normal slices of sashimi... Spicy tuna roll was passable... Dinner for 3 was about $100. Thank goodness voucher reduced it to $60. But we had to look for another place for our second dinner because we left the restaurant very unsatisfied and generally unhappy. ... Thank goodness dinner no.2 that night turned out good

photos.caption: Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. This is on the menu as "thick slice". Waitress needed to ask the kitchen to confirm if order was right
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy tuna. Passable
Photo of Senmi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Flat flat flat....

WRlKlbHlYgBNIvopUhf4VQ.text: Simple, fresh sushi place. The sashimi is great. Being Singapore, the prices are ridiculous... (On that note, the rolls look good value for money, though have not tried any of them so can't speak to how they are). The venue is simple, casual, exactly as you would expect from a place that is attached to a supermarket!  Likely to be back, for a casual lunch.

qRg52ERnP8Sk-D_G0DfVaQ.text: This sushi joint is part of Emporium Shokuhin, a new gourmet supermarket with 7 restaurants, a takeaway sushi section and a very hyped up bunch of seafood tanks and steak room. My colleagues and I were pretty darn excited about a Japanese market opening near our office, since the Suntec/Millenia/Marina Sq area is pretty much the dead zone for value (read value, not affordable, since that doesn't exist in the vicinity) meals for lunch. Unfortunately, we got a little too excited and were brought down to earth quickly at our visit to the sushi bar last week.Senmi Sushi IS located in a supermarket and high end as it may be, I do expect *some* value . We ordered the chirashi and wagyu beef roll, which are the specialties and I thought the former was mediocre. The chirashi came with fairly standard fish, portions that left us wondering where we should get some mee pok afterwards, and at a price tag that was a little lofty. I didn't mind the lack of variety as much as I minded the portions because honey, there ain't nothing worse than under-feeding a hungry office worker with only an hour to spare. The beef roll scored way better on the value card, with some delicious slices of beef wrapped around a shrimp tempura roll and covered in some mystery sauce with crunchy crumbs. Again at about $18 (if I recall correctly), you were getting what you paid for. My advice is to stick with Teppei at Millennia Walk, where you get a humongous bowl of Kaisendon for about $17 and they creatively offer a salad option if you're on a no-carb diet. There's also a restaurant in Purvis St that does a very generous $25 bowl but I find the slices too thick and jelat. Besides the food, I liked the decor (a calming zen aesthetic) but that was about it. We came during their opening week so the front of house was really disorganized. The restaurant has a long sushi bar and a row of tables that were, well, long. Since most office folk eat in 2's, every table had enough space for 2-4 more people but  was underutilized, so there was a long line of people watching empty table space. We were initially seated at the sushi bar, which has iPad's for every 2 people. However, the waiter thought it was necessary to consolidate our order on one iPad and turned the other one off, so we all had to take turns moving to the seat with the glorious functioning iPad to place our orders. The face -palm-worth use of technology was made worse by the fact that every iPad (at the counter and tables) was connected to a cable on the wall that was about 15cm long. So be warned, you're gonna get really chummy with your colleagues while trying to peruse the menu and order at this sushi joint. Lastly, our orders (which if you notice was mostly raw) took almost an hour to get to us and it was only after we asked about them that they magically appeared within seconds.Not a fun opening week experience but if you're desperate (and you probably are) for a change of scene with sushi, this is it. Just uh, save a couple of bucks for mee pok afterwards because you will be hungry. Or just eat the takeaway sushi in the emporium itself.

w9QCmwEznaPkaP3v_vO-dQ.text: This is a great place for sashimi and sushi. Very fresh. Chirashi dons are good value meals.
